revisionDesc.change:
Vote - AcceptText - l1: => ⲡϣⲉ] [ⲛⲡ]ⲁⲗⲉⲛⲏ; => ⲛ]<:[ⲁⲃⲣⲁϩⲁ]ⲙ|alt|[ⲡⲁϩⲁ]ⲙ:> l2: => ⲛϣⲙⲟⲩⲛ] [ⲧ]<:πόλις=grc|reg|ⲡⲟⲗⲓⲥ:> l3, 5, 6, 7, 9: remove line breaks; l3: => ⲭⲣ̣[ⲉⲱⲥ]ⲧⲉ l4: I'd prefer: [ⲛ]<:εὔσταθμον=grc|reg|(ⲉⲩⲥ(ⲧⲁ)ⲑ(ⲙⲟⲛ)):> <:Ἀλεξανδρείας=grc|reg|(ⲁⲗ(ⲉ)ⲝ(ⲁⲛⲇⲣⲉⲓⲁⲥ)):> l7: => ⲡⲉⲩϫⲁⲓ] [ⲛⲛ]ⲉⲛϫⲓⲥⲟⲟⲩⲉ l8: => ⲡⲁⲡⲉ l10: => ⲛⲑⲉ] [ⲉⲥⲥ]ⲏ̣ϩ̣ ; => *stauros?* l12: => (γεναμ(έν)η) (there is no need for reg.); As for the symbol before Phibammonos: It seems to me rather (π(αρὰ)) then ((διὰ)), but I'd like another opinion as well. (I have checked the image online.); (Φιβ(άμμωνος)) => Φὶβ, at least this is how Till understood it (see tranlation). He must be the same person as in l1 and l8. What is marked as an abbreviation stroke after Phib could be the left part of a κ, perhaps => (κ(αὶ))
Some further comments based on the image: l12: I'd prefer => (γεναμ(ένη)) or (γεναμέ(νη)), γεναμ(έν)η would be an odd abbreviation. ((καὶ)) => (κ(αὶ)) (as said before) <:Γεωργίου|reg|Γεωρ:> (I see no abbreviation mark.) A dating to the sixth century would be more likely in my view (cf. e.g. the form of the para abbreviation.)
Entré le texte copte. Il n'y a rien à la fin du texte, là où Till met [?. Et j'ai décidé d'après la photo de l'endroit où mettre le texte qui se trouve entre les lignes 2 et 3
